challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: On Election Day, any registered voter rightfully in the polling place (including a candidate, poll watcher and official observer) may challenge the right to vote of any person who comes to the precinct officials for voting purposes. Prior to Election Day, any registered voter may challenge the right of a person to be or to remain registered as a voter in any precinct.
Challenges are permitted at the polls on Election Day.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

subtopics.fact: On Election Day, the challenge may only be on the grounds that the voter is not the person the voter alleges to be, or that the voter is not a resident of that precinct; provided that only in an election of members of the board of trustees of the office of Hawaiian affairs, a person registered to vote in that election may also challenge on the grounds that the voter is not Hawaiian. No other or further challenge shall be allowed. For a challenge made prior to Election Day, a voter's right to remain registered as a voter in any precinct may be made for any cause not previously decided by the board of registration or the supreme court in respect to the same person.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?
Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact: For an Election Day challenge, any challenged voter shall first be given the opportunity to make the relevant correction. The challenge shall be considered and decided immediately by the precinct officials and the ruling shall be announced.
subtopics.subtopic: How does a voter defend their eligibility to vote if they are challenged?

subtopics.fact: Poll workers have the right to request ID of any voter, so it's best for voters to bring ID with them on Election Day. In addition, first-time voters who did not register in person with a government official and did not provide ID with their registration form must present ID at the polls.
subtopics.subtopic: Who must show ID to vote?

subtopics.fact: First-time voters may present: (1) a current and valid photo identification; or (2) a copy of a current utility bill, bank statement, government check, paycheck, or other government document that shows the name and address of the voter. The only requirement for other voters is that the ID be "valid identification." The NVRAC card is not an acceptable form of identification. However, acceptable types of ID are not specified by law.

citations: E-mail from the Hawaii Office of Elections on 7/28/10
subtopics.fact: If the voter has no identification, the voter will be asked to recite their date of birth and residence address to corroborate the information provided in the poll book.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?

citations: E-mail from the Hawaii Office of Elections on 8/31/2011
subtopics.fact: If the ID is issued by a public university and shows the voter's address, it should qualify. However, if a voter does not have this type of student ID, they can state their birthdate and address and should be allowed to vote a regular ballot.
subtopics.subtopic: Is a student ID an acceptable form of identification?
